claim: London gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: London is one of the world's most visited cities, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.

attacks.text: London is one of the world's most visited cities, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, surpassing Paris.
Paris also reports over 20 million international arrivals annually, making the difference statistically insignificant.
London's numbers may include transit passengers who do not actually visit the city, inflating the arrival statistics.
Independent audits confirm London's arrivals data excludes transit passengers, ensuring accuracy.
Paris's tourism board uses stricter counting methods, potentially underreporting actual arrivals compared to London.

supporting.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest in the world by international passenger traffic, contributing to higher arrivals than Paris.

attacks.text: London's Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest in the world by international passenger traffic, contributing to higher arrivals than Paris.
Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport also ranks among the busiest globally, with comparable international passenger traffic to Heathrow.
Many international travelers to Paris arrive via other airports like Orly or via high-speed rail, which Heathrow's data doesn't account for.
Heathrow's passenger numbers include a significant portion of transit passengers who don't actually enter London, inflating the arrivals count.
Charles de Gaulle's connectivity to other European hubs means it handles more direct international arrivals, not just transit passengers.
Orly Airport primarily serves domestic and short-haul European flights, contributing minimally to international arrivals compared to Heathrow.
High-speed rail arrivals are not counted as international air passengers, making the comparison to Heathrow's data misleading.

supporting.text: The UK's stronger global air connectivity, with more direct international flights to London, results in higher arrivals compared to Paris.

attacks.text: The UK's stronger global air connectivity, with more direct international flights to London, results in higher arrivals compared to Paris.
Paris has a more centralized location in Europe, making it a preferred transit hub for many international travelers.
The UK's visa policies are stricter than France's, potentially deterring some international travelers from choosing London.
London's airports have higher capacity and more runways, allowing for a greater number of international flights despite Paris's central location.
France's Schengen Area membership makes Paris more accessible to travelers from within Europe, offsetting any advantage from London's air connectivity.
The UK's strong cultural and economic ties with non-EU countries compensate for stricter visa policies, maintaining high arrival numbers.

supporting.text: London hosts major global events and business hubs, attracting more international visitors annually than Paris.

attacks.text: London hosts major global events and business hubs, attracting more international visitors annually than Paris.
Paris also hosts significant global events like Fashion Week and major business conferences, which attract comparable numbers of visitors.
Tourism data from recent years shows Paris often surpasses London in international arrivals due to its cultural landmarks.
London's business hubs are more diversified, attracting a broader range of international visitors beyond tourism.
The methodology of tourism data collection varies, and London's transit hub status may undercount actual visitor numbers.
Paris's cultural landmarks are unique and draw visitors consistently, regardless of business diversification in London.

supporting.text: Paris remains a top tourist destination, with iconic attractions like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, potentially rivaling London's arrivals.

attacks.text: Paris remains a top tourist destination, with iconic attractions like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, potentially rivaling London's arrivals.
London has a more extensive and efficient public transport system, making it easier for tourists to explore multiple attractions, thus increasing its international arrivals.
London hosts more international business events and conferences, which significantly contribute to higher visitor numbers compared to Paris.
Paris's public transport system is also highly efficient and covers all major tourist attractions, making it equally accessible for tourists.
Many international business events in London are attended by the same recurring delegates, which does not necessarily translate to higher unique international arrivals.
London's public transport system is more integrated with international airports, providing a seamless experience for international travelers.
The number of unique international attendees at London's business events has been consistently high, as evidenced by event registration data.

supporting.text: France's tourism industry is highly developed, and Paris benefits from its central location in Europe, possibly matching London's arrivals.

attacks.text: France's tourism industry is highly developed, and Paris benefits from its central location in Europe, possibly matching London's arrivals.
London has consistently ranked higher than Paris in international visitor numbers according to recent tourism reports.
London's status as a global financial hub attracts more business travelers, increasing its international arrivals.
The English language's global dominance makes London more accessible to international visitors than Paris.
Paris has seen a decline in tourism due to recent social unrest and strikes, affecting its international arrivals.
Business travel has been declining globally, which may reduce London's advantage in international arrivals.
Many international visitors are multilingual and do not face significant language barriers in Paris.
